title: 104_hr3992
content: The "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program, established by the "Medicare Commission Act of 1996," consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members are selected from various backgrounds, with limitations on political party affiliations. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members are selected from various backgrounds, with limitations on political party affiliations. The appointments of the Commission members must be made within 3 months of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chairman. The Commission, consisting of 15 members appointed by various officials, must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Chairman calls meetings, a majority of members form a quorum, and the Commission selects a Chairman from its members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing analyses of Medicare trust funds, identifying solvency threats, analyzing potential solutions, and providing recommendations to ensure financial integrity and health benefits under the Medicare Program. The term "Medicare trust funds" refers to the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. Congressional leaders will introduce legislation based on the Commission's recommendations within 3 months. Leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives will introduce legislation within 3 months based on recommendations from a report for the long-term solvency of the Medicare trust funds. If the House does not vote on the legislation within 3 months of its introduction, the relevant committee will be treated as having considered it. The House and Senate must vote on introduced legislation within 3 months, or the relevant committee will be discharged from consideration. A motion to proceed with the legislation will be treated as highly privileged. Legislation referred to a committee will be discharged if not voted on within 3 months. A motion to proceed with the legislation will be treated as privileged. The House of Representatives grants high privilege to consider a joint resolution endorsing recommendations from a report and providing legislative authority for those recommendations. The Commission established by the joint resolution has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission has authority over personnel matters. The Commission members who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Private citizens on the Commission also serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Chairman of the Commission may appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative support. Compensation for staff can be determined by the Chairman without following specific regulations. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Funding for the Commission will come from available funds for the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
